H0.text: Mean material densities is the difference between land and water that contributes most directly to global climate change resulting from tectonic movement.

H1.text: Magnetic material content is the difference between land and water that contributes most directly to global climate change resulting from tectonic movement.

H2.text: Heat absorption and retention properties are the difference between land and water that contributes most directly to global climate change resulting from tectonic movement.

H3.text: Rate of radioactivity‑related heat release is the difference between land and water that contributes most directly to global climate change resulting from tectonic movement.

A4.text: Increased carbon uptake from afforestation results in reduced albedo. Initially, this reduction may lead to moderate global warming over a span of approximately 20 years, but it is expected to transition into significant cooling thereafter.

A5.text: Urbanization generally decreases albedo (commonly being 0.01–0.02 lower than adjacent croplands), which contributes to global warming.
